(41) 251.October 28, 1941.TO BE KEPT UNDER LOCK AND KEY.It is requested that special care may be taken toensure the secrecy of this document.WAR CABINET.MILITARY AID FOR RUSSIA.Memorandum by the Minister of Supply.I CIRCULATE for the information of my colleagues the following extractfrom notes of conversations with Stalin written by Mr. Harriman. I havereceived by telephone to-night Mr. Ffarriman's permission to quote any part ofhis narrative : -" There was considerable discussion all the way through the talkregarding British military co-operation with Russia."'' Beaverbrook offered strategic discussions with General Ismay duringthe conference, and invited the Russians to send a mission to England toconsider the British problem and give advice on what might be done, pluseducation on what the Russians had learned in their recent battles with theGermans."'' He indicated that the British were building up divisions in Persiawhich might be joined in the Caucasus with the Russians. Wavell was proceeding to Tiflis for conversations along these lines. Stalin commented:' There is no war in the Caucasus, but there is in the Ukraine.' Beaverbrookindicated that this might be taken up, too."" Beaverbrook asked Stalin if he thought Britain could invade France.Stalin said he didn't know enough about the situation, but had confidence inChurchilFs judgment, but why not send a force to Archangel or theUkraine? "B.October 28, 1941.
